article.title: Mixing Spectrum in Reduced Phase Spaces of Stochastic Differential Equations. Part II: Stochastic Hopf Bifurcation

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the triangular structure of eigenvalues in Figure 4(c) represent?
choices: Stochastically forced nonlinear oscillations with phase diffusion
A stable steady state perturbed by noise below a bifurcation point
A perturbed limit cycle above a bifurcation point

multiple_choice_question.text: What causes the parabolic shape of the eigenvalue array in Figure 4(d)?
choices: The presence of a stable steady state.
Phase diffusion due to noise along the limit cycle.
The triangular structure of eigenvalues below the bifurcation point.
The non-mixing nature of the deterministic dynamics on the limit cycle.

multiple_choice_question.text: In the phase diffusion equation (2.21), what are the two contributions to the evolution of the phase φ?
choices: Advection at constant angular velocity and uniform diffusion.
Advection at constant angular velocity and nonuniform diffusion.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the coefficient Φ in formula (6.1) measure?
choices: The rate of decay of correlations in a stochastic Hopf bifurcation.
The degree of non-normality of the Jacobian matrix associated with the limit cycle.
The effect of the interaction of the noise with the deterministic vector field integrated over one period of the limit cycle.
The difference in structure between the RP spectrum below and above the bifurcation point.
